articles.title: Waitlist Management
articles.summary:
NEW IN V1.1: Manage patient waitlist with auto-notifications

Access via Practice Management > Waitlist tab. Set priority levels and automatically notify patients when slots open.
articles.content:
**NEW IN V1.1:** Waitlist now fully integrated into Practice Management!

**Accessing Waitlist:**
1. Go to Practice Management module
2. Click the 'Waitlist' tab (next to List and Calendar)
3. View all patients with status tracking

**Adding Patient to Waitlist:**

**Method 1 - From Appointment Scheduling:**
1. Attempt to schedule appointment
2. If no slots available, click 'Add to Waitlist'
3. Fill in waitlist details
4. Click Save

**Method 2 - Directly from Waitlist Tab:**
1. Go to Practice Management > Waitlist
2. Click '+ Add to Waitlist' button
3. Complete the form
4. Click Save

**Required Fields:**
â€¢ Patient (search and select)
â€¢ Provider (preferred provider)
â€¢ Appointment Type
â€¢ Priority (High/Medium/Low)

**Optional Fields:**
â€¢ Preferred Date Range
â€¢ Preferred Time (Morning/Afternoon/Any)
â€¢ Reason for visit
â€¢ Internal notes

**Priority Levels:**
ðŸ”´ HIGH - Urgent medical need, time-sensitive follow-up (notified first)
ðŸŸ¡ MEDIUM - Standard follow-up, moderately important (notified second)
ðŸŸ¢ LOW - Routine check-up, flexible timing (notified last)

**Status Tracking:**
â€¢ Active - Waiting for appointment slot
â€¢ Notified - Patient notified of available slot
â€¢ Scheduled - Appointment has been scheduled
â€¢ Cancelled - Patient no longer needs appointment
â€¢ Expired - Patient didn't respond within timeframe

**Auto-Notification System:**
When matching slot becomes available:
1. System identifies matches (provider, type, preferences)
2. Sorts by priority (High > Medium > Low) and date
3. Notifies highest-priority patient via SMS, email, portal
4. Updates status to 'Notified'
5. Patient has 24 hours to confirm

**Confirming Appointments:**
When patient responds 'Yes':
1. Click 'Confirm Appointment' next to entry
2. System automatically creates appointment
3. Updates status to 'Scheduled'
4. Sends confirmation to patient
5. Removes from active waitlist

When patient responds 'No' or doesn't respond:
1. Click 'Move to Next'
2. Original entry marked 'Expired'
3. Next priority patient automatically notified

**Best Practices:**
â€¢ Reserve High priority for medically urgent cases
â€¢ Document patient preferences in notes
â€¢ Review waitlist daily for expired entries
â€¢ Call high-priority patients proactively
â€¢ Clean up entries older than 30 days
â€¢ Verify patient contact information is current

articles.title: Provider Scheduling
articles.summary:
Manage provider availability and working hours

Set up provider schedules, block time for meetings or procedures, and manage time-off requests.
articles.content:
**Managing Provider Schedules:**

**Accessing Provider Scheduling:**
1. Go to Administration > Providers
2. Select a provider
3. Click 'Manage Schedule' tab
4. Or go to Practice Management > Provider Schedules

**Setting Up Provider Availability:**

**Regular Working Hours:**
1. Click 'Set Schedule' button
2. For each day of week:
   â€¢ Toggle working day on/off
   â€¢ Set start time (e.g., 8:00 AM)
   â€¢ Set end time (e.g., 5:00 PM)
   â€¢ Add lunch break (optional)
   â€¢ Add multiple time blocks per day

**Example Schedule:**
Monday - Friday:
â€¢ 8:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Morning)
â€¢ 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM (Lunch - Blocked)
â€¢ 1:00 PM - 5:00 PM (Afternoon)

Saturday:
â€¢ 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM (Half day)

Sunday:
â€¢ Closed

**Appointment Slot Configuration:**

**Default Slot Duration:**
â€¢ 15 minutes - Quick follow-ups
â€¢ 30 minutes - Standard office visits
â€¢ 45 minutes - New patient visits
â€¢ 60 minutes - Physicals, consultations

**Buffer Time:**
â€¢ Between appointments (5-10 min)
â€¢ Prevents back-to-back scheduling
â€¢ Allows for charting/documentation
â€¢ Accounts for running late

**Appointment Types by Duration:**
1. Click 'Appointment Types'
2. Set custom duration for each type:
   â€¢ Office Visit: 30 min
   â€¢ Annual Physical: 60 min
   â€¢ Follow-up: 15 min
   â€¢ Procedure: varies
   â€¢ Telehealth: 20 min

**Blocking Time:**

**One-Time Blocks:**
1. Go to provider's calendar
2. Click time slot to block
3. Select 'Block Time'
4. Choose reason:
   â€¢ Meeting/Conference
   â€¢ Procedure/Surgery
   â€¢ Administrative Time
   â€¢ Training
   â€¢ Personal
5. Set start and end time
6. Add notes (optional)
7. Click 'Save Block'

**Recurring Blocks:**
For regular commitments:
1. Click 'Create Recurring Block'
2. Set schedule:
   â€¢ Every Tuesday 2:00-3:00 PM
   â€¢ First Monday of month
   â€¢ Every other Wednesday
3. Set recurrence pattern:
   â€¢ Daily
   â€¢ Weekly (select days)
   â€¢ Monthly (select date or day)
   â€¢ Custom
4. Set end date or number of occurrences
5. Reason and notes
6. Save

**Common Recurring Blocks:**
â€¢ Weekly staff meetings
â€¢ Monthly quality review
â€¢ Thursday afternoon procedures
â€¢ Every other Friday administrative time

**Time Off Management:**

**Requesting Time Off:**
1. Go to My Schedule > Request Time Off
2. Select type:
   â€¢ Vacation
   â€¢ Sick Leave
   â€¢ Conference/CME
   â€¢ Personal Day
   â€¢ Holiday
3. Select date range
4. Add notes/justification
5. Submit request

**Approving Time Off (Admins):**
1. Go to Administration > Time Off Requests
2. Review pending requests
3. Check coverage for dates
4. Approve or deny with notes
5. System blocks calendar automatically
6. Notifies provider of decision

**When Time Off Approved:**
â€¢ Calendar blocked for date range
â€¢ Existing appointments flagged for rescheduling
â€¢ New appointments prevented during period
â€¢ Out-of-office message can be set
â€¢ Coverage provider assigned (optional)

**Coverage Providers:**

**Assigning Coverage:**
When provider is out:
1. Set time off period
2. Click 'Assign Coverage'
3. Select covering provider(s)
4. Set rules:
   â€¢ Transfer all appointments
   â€¢ Only urgent/same-day
   â€¢ By appointment type
5. Notify patients of change (optional)
6. Existing appointments updated

**Multiple Locations:**

If provider works at multiple locations:
1. Go to Provider > Locations
2. Add each location
3. Set schedule per location:
   â€¢ Monday/Wednesday - Main Office
   â€¢ Tuesday/Thursday - Satellite Clinic
   â€¢ Friday - Hospital Rounds
4. Calendar shows location for each slot
5. Appointments automatically tagged with location

**Appointment Limits:**

**Daily Limits:**
Prevent overbooking:
1. Set max appointments per day
2. Set max new patients per day
3. Set max specific appointment types
4. System warns when approaching limit
5. Admin override available if needed

**Example Limits:**
â€¢ Max 20 appointments/day
â€¢ Max 4 new patients/day
â€¢ Max 2 annual physicals/day
â€¢ Max 5 telehealth visits/day

**Emergency/ASAP Slots:**

**Reserved Slots:**
1. Block specific slots daily for urgent visits
2. Example: 11:00 AM and 3:00 PM
3. Only bookable as 'Urgent' or 'Same-Day'
4. Auto-released if not used by cutoff time
5. Cutoff: 2 hours before slot time

**Override Scheduling:**

**Double Booking:**
For emergencies/urgent needs:
1. Attempt to book filled slot
2. System shows conflict warning
3. Select 'Override - Urgent'
4. Add justification
5. Provider notified of double-book
6. Appears as overlapping on calendar

**Outside Working Hours:**
1. Attempt to book blocked time
2. System warns 'Outside working hours'
3. Admin can override
4. Provider notified
5. Requires approval if provider settings require it

**Schedule Templates:**

**Creating Templates:**
1. Set up ideal weekly schedule
2. Include:
   â€¢ Working hours
   â€¢ Blocked time
   â€¢ Appointment types distribution
   â€¢ Buffer times
3. Save as template
4. Apply to future weeks with one click

**Template Use Cases:**
â€¢ Seasonal schedules (summer vs winter)
â€¢ Rotating schedules
â€¢ New provider onboarding
â€¢ Standardizing across providers

**Schedule Reports:**

**Available Reports:**
â€¢ Provider utilization (% of time booked)
â€¢ No-show rate by provider
â€¢ Average appointment duration
â€¢ Peak appointment times
â€¢ Cancellation patterns
â€¢ Time off summary
â€¢ Revenue per provider hour

**Best Practices:**
â€¢ Set realistic appointment durations
â€¢ Build in buffer time for documentation
â€¢ Reserve slots for urgent/same-day
â€¢ Review and update schedule quarterly
â€¢ Communicate schedule changes in advance
â€¢ Use templates for consistency
â€¢ Monitor utilization to optimize
â€¢ Block administrative time for charting
â€¢ Coordinate time off with colleagues
â€¢ Set automatic lunch blocks
â€¢ Review no-shows and adjust overbooking
â€¢ Use recurring blocks for standing commitments
â€¢ Assign coverage for all absences
â€¢ Keep contact info current for notifications

Register new patients and set up portal access

**Registering New Patients:**

**Accessing Registration:**
1. Go to Patients module
2. Click '+ New Patient' button

**Registration Process - 5 Steps:**

**STEP 1: Demographics**

**Required Fields:**
â€¢ First Name
â€¢ Last Name
â€¢ Date of Birth
â€¢ Gender (Male, Female, Other, Prefer not to say)
â€¢ Phone Number (primary contact)
â€¢ Email Address

**Optional Fields:**
â€¢ Middle Name
â€¢ Preferred Name (what patient likes to be called)
â€¢ Suffix (Jr., Sr., III)
â€¢ SSN (last 4 digits or full, encrypted)
â€¢ Language Preference
â€¢ Race/Ethnicity (for reporting)
â€¢ Marital Status
â€¢ Occupation

**Address Information:**
â€¢ Street Address
â€¢ Apartment/Unit Number
â€¢ City
â€¢ State/Province
â€¢ ZIP/Postal Code
â€¢ Country

**Additional Contact:**
â€¢ Secondary Phone (mobile/work)
â€¢ Preferred Contact Method (Phone, Email, SMS, Portal)
â€¢ Best Time to Call

**STEP 2: Insurance Information**

**Primary Insurance:**
â€¢ Insurance Company (search from list or add new)
â€¢ Policy/Member ID Number
â€¢ Group Number
â€¢ Policy Holder Name (if different from patient)
â€¢ Policy Holder DOB
â€¢ Relationship to Patient (Self, Spouse, Parent, Other)
â€¢ Effective Date

  - Front (required)
  - Back (required)

Same fields as primary insurance

2. System checks eligibility in real-time
3. Displays:
   â€¢ Active/Inactive status
   â€¢ Copay amount
   â€¢ Deductible status
   â€¢ Coverage details

**STEP 3: Emergency Contact**

**Primary Emergency Contact:**
â€¢ Full Name
â€¢ Relationship to Patient
â€¢ Phone Number (home)
â€¢ Mobile Phone
â€¢ Email Address
â€¢ Address (if different from patient)

**Secondary Emergency Contact (Optional):**
Same fields as primary contact

**STEP 4: Medical History (Optional)**

Can be completed now or during first visit:
â€¢ Allergies
â€¢ Current Medications
â€¢ Past Medical History
â€¢ Family History
â€¢ Social History
â€¢ Surgical History

**STEP 5: Portal Access**

**Enable Patient Portal:**
1. Toggle 'Enable Portal Access'
2. Patient receives email invitation
3. Email contains:
   â€¢ Portal URL
   â€¢ Temporary password or setup link
   â€¢ Instructions for first login

**Portal Features:**
â€¢ View medical records
â€¢ Schedule appointments
â€¢ Request prescription refills
â€¢ Message providers
â€¢ View test results
â€¢ Pay bills online
â€¢ Update personal information

**Portal Setup Options:**
â€¢ Send invitation immediately
â€¢ Send invitation later
â€¢ Generate temporary password
â€¢ Require patient to set password on first login

**Completing Registration:**

1. Review all information
2. Click 'Save Patient' button
3. System generates:
   â€¢ MRN (Medical Record Number) - auto-assigned
   â€¢ Patient ID
   â€¢ Chart number
4. Patient added to system
5. Portal invitation sent (if enabled)

**After Registration:**

**Immediate Actions:**
â€¢ Schedule first appointment
â€¢ Add to waitlist if no availability
â€¢ Collect copay/payment
â€¢ Scan insurance cards
â€¢ Provide new patient forms
â€¢ Give office policies handout

**Patient Chart Created:**
â€¢ Empty chart ready for documentation
â€¢ Demographics populated
â€¢ Insurance information loaded
â€¢ Portal access configured
â€¢ Ready for clinical use

**Quick Registration (Walk-In):**

For urgent/walk-in patients:
1. Click 'Quick Registration'
2. Minimal fields required:
   â€¢ Name
   â€¢ Date of Birth
   â€¢ Phone Number
3. Complete full registration later
4. System flags chart as 'Incomplete'

**Duplicate Detection:**

System checks for duplicates based on:
â€¢ First Name + Last Name + DOB
â€¢ SSN (if provided)
â€¢ Phone Number + DOB

If potential duplicate found:
1. System displays warning
2. Shows matching patient(s)

**Required Documents:**

articles.content:
**Managing Patient Diagnoses:**

**Accessing Diagnoses:**
1. Open patient chart
2. Click 'Problems' or 'Diagnoses' tab
3. View active and past diagnoses

**Problem List Overview:**

**Active Problems:**
Conditions currently being treated or monitored
â€¢ Chronic diseases (Diabetes, Hypertension)
â€¢ Acute conditions (Infections, injuries)
â€¢ Ongoing issues requiring management

**Chronic Problems:**
Long-term conditions (subset of active)
â€¢ Marked separately for easy identification
â€¢ Typically require ongoing medication
â€¢ Need regular monitoring

**Past/Resolved Problems:**
â€¢ Previously active, now resolved
â€¢ Kept for historical reference
â€¢ Not shown in active problem list
â€¢ Available in medical history

**Adding New Diagnosis:**

**Method 1 - From Problem List:**
1. Open patient chart
2. Go to 'Problems' tab
3. Click '+ Add Diagnosis'
4. Search for diagnosis

**Method 2 - From Clinical Note:**
1. In SOAP note Assessment section
2. Type diagnosis name or code
3. Select from dropdown
4. Automatically added to problem list

**Method 3 - From Prescription:**
1. When prescribing medication
2. Step 4: Link to diagnosis
3. Can add new diagnosis on-the-fly

**Searching for Diagnoses:**

**ICD-10 Code Search:**
Multiple search methods:

**By Description:**
â€¢ Type: "diabetes"
â€¢ Shows all diabetes-related codes:
  - E11.9 - Type 2 Diabetes without complications
  - E11.65 - Type 2 Diabetes with hyperglycemia
  - E10.9 - Type 1 Diabetes
  - E11.22 - Type 2 Diabetes with chronic kidney disease

**By ICD-10 Code:**
â€¢ Type: "E11.9"
â€¢ Direct match displayed
â€¢ Related codes suggested

**By Body System:**
â€¢ Browse categories:
  - Endocrine (E codes)
  - Circulatory (I codes)

**Smart Search Features:**
â€¢ Autocomplete as you type
â€¢ Shows code + description
â€¢ Recently used codes at top

â€¢ Synonym recognition ("sugar diabetes" = diabetes mellitus)

**Diagnosis Details:**

**Required Fields:**
â€¢ ICD-10 Code (e.g., E11.9)
â€¢ Description (auto-filled from code)
â€¢ Date of Onset
â€¢ Status (Active, Chronic, Resolved)

**Optional Fields:**
â€¢ Severity (Mild, Moderate, Severe)
â€¢ Laterality (Left, Right, Bilateral) - if applicable
â€¢ Stage/Grade (for cancers, ulcers, etc.)
â€¢ Clinical Notes
â€¢ Treating Provider
â€¢ Date Resolved (if applicable)

**Status Types:**

**Active:**
Currently being treated
â€¢ Shows in active problem list
â€¢ Included in encounter documentation
â€¢ Available for linking to orders/prescriptions

**Chronic:**
Ongoing, long-term condition
â€¢ Subset of Active
â€¢ Flagged for special tracking
â€¢ Requires regular monitoring
â€¢ Examples: Diabetes, Hypertension, Asthma

**Resolved:**
No longer active
â€¢ Moves to past medical history
â€¢ Not in active problem list
â€¢ Available for reference
â€¢ Date resolved documented

**Rule Out:**
Differential diagnosis, not confirmed
â€¢ Appears with "R/O" prefix
â€¢ Used during workup
â€¢ Update to Active or Remove after testing

**Linking Diagnoses:**

**Link to Prescriptions:**

When prescribing medication:
1. ePrescribe Step 4
2. Select primary diagnosis for prescription
3. Improves claim approval
4. Documents medical necessity

**Example:**
Prescribing Metformin â†’ Link to E11.9 (Type 2 Diabetes)

**Link to Lab Orders:**

When ordering labs:
1. Step 1: Clinical Indication required
2. Select diagnosis from problem list

**Example:**
Ordering A1C â†’ Link to E11.9 (Type 2 Diabetes)

**Link to Procedures:**

For procedures and billing:
1. Procedure requires diagnosis pointer
2. Select applicable diagnosis(es)
3. Up to 12 diagnoses per claim
4. Primary diagnosis listed first

**Link to Encounters:**

In clinical note:
1. Assessment section lists diagnoses
2. Mark primary diagnosis for visit
3. Links to E&M code for billing
4. Supports level of service billed

**Managing Existing Diagnoses:**

**Editing:**

   â€¢ Change status

   â€¢ Modify date

**Resolving:**
1. Click diagnosis
2. Click 'Mark as Resolved'

**Deleting:**
Only if added in error:
1. Click diagnosis
2. Click 'Delete'
3. Confirm deletion
4. Provide reason

**Problem List Best Practices:**

**Keep it Current:**
â€¢ Review at every visit
â€¢ Resolve conditions that are inactive
â€¢ Update status as conditions change
â€¢ Remove duplicate entries

**Be Specific:**
â€¢ Use most specific ICD-10 code available
â€¢ E11.65 (with hyperglycemia) vs E11.9 (unspecified)
â€¢ Include laterality when relevant
â€¢ Document stage/severity

**Prioritize:**
â€¢ List most significant problems first
â€¢ Mark chronic conditions clearly
â€¢ Identify primary diagnosis for visit

**Link Everything:**
â€¢ Link prescriptions to diagnoses
â€¢ Link lab orders to diagnoses
â€¢ Link procedures to diagnoses
â€¢ Improves claims approval
â€¢ Documents medical necessity

**Common Diagnosis Scenarios:**

**Multiple Related Diagnoses:**

Example - Diabetes complications:
â€¢ E11.9 - Type 2 Diabetes (primary)
â€¢ E11.22 - Type 2 Diabetes with CKD (if kidney disease present)
â€¢ E11.36 - Type 2 Diabetes with diabetic neuropathy
â€¢ E11.319 - Type 2 Diabetes with diabetic retinopathy

Keep all relevant codes active for comprehensive documentation.

**Combination Codes:**

Some conditions have single combined codes:
â€¢ I10 - Essential Hypertension (use instead of separate codes)
â€¢ J44.0 - COPD with acute lower respiratory infection (not COPD + pneumonia separately)

Use combination code when available.

**Diagnosis Hierarchy:**

For claims and documentation:
1. Primary Diagnosis - Main reason for visit/service
2. Secondary Diagnoses - Contributing factors
3. Additional Diagnoses - Other relevant conditions

**Quality Measures:**

Certain diagnoses trigger quality reporting:
â€¢ Diabetes â†’ A1C testing required
â€¢ Hypertension â†’ BP control monitoring
â€¢ COPD â†’ Spirometry testing
â€¢ Depression â†’ PHQ-9 screening

**Diagnosis Reports:**

â€¢ Quality Measure Compliance

**Using Reports:**
1. Go to Reports module
2. Select 'Diagnosis Reports'
3. Choose report type
4. Set filters (date range, provider, diagnosis)
5. Generate and export

**ICD-10 Code Updates:**

**Annual Updates:**
October 1st each year:
â€¢ New codes added
â€¢ Some codes deleted
â€¢ Descriptions modified
â€¢ System auto-updates

**When Code Changes:**
â€¢ System notifies affected charts
â€¢ Recommend updating to new code
â€¢ Old code still visible in history
â€¢ Update prospectively, not retrospectively

**Best Practices:**
â€¢ Use most specific code possible (5-6 characters)
â€¢ Include laterality when applicable (right vs left)
â€¢ Document stage/severity for cancers
â€¢ Link all prescriptions to diagnoses
â€¢ Keep problem list current and accurate
â€¢ Resolve inactive problems
â€¢ Use chronic designation appropriately
â€¢ Review problem list at each visit
â€¢ Verify diagnoses support procedures/tests ordered
â€¢ Use combination codes when available
â€¢ Don't use unspecified codes if more specific available
â€¢ Document onset dates accurately
â€¢ Include patient in problem list review
â€¢ Use consistent terminology
â€¢ Avoid outdated or obsolete codes

**Drip Campaigns:**

**What are Drip Campaigns?**
Automated series of messages over time.

**Example - New Patient Onboarding:**
â€¢ Day 1: Welcome email with portal setup
â€¢ Day 3: SMS reminder to complete health history
â€¢ Day 7: Email about services and offerings
â€¢ Day 14: Survey about first visit experience

**Example - Chronic Care Management:**
â€¢ Week 1: Educational content about condition

â€¢ Week 4: Schedule follow-up appointment
â€¢ Repeat monthly with new content

**A/B Testing:**

**Testing Variables:**
â€¢ Subject lines
â€¢ Send times
â€¢ Message length
â€¢ Call-to-action wording
â€¢ Images vs. text-only
â€¢ Sender name

**How to A/B Test:**
1. Create two versions (A and B)
2. Split audience 50/50
3. Send simultaneously
4. Compare performance
5. Use winner for future campaigns
